title: The underside of the Suspension Bridge transformed into the Underworld
text:
A theatre company in Bristol is gearing up for a performance in a rather unusual venue.
Rather than treading the boards, actors will- for the first time- descend into the vaults beneath the Clifton Suspension Bridge.
The vast chambers were only re-discovered in 2002 and from tomorrow, groups of theatre-goers will be given a rare glimpse at the hidden depths of the landmark.
Credit: ITV News The story of Orpheus & Eurydice has been told and retold over thousands of years, but this is a performance like no other.
Hannah Drake, the play's director said, "Orpheus and Eurydice are famous lovers from Greek myth. They are as famous as Romeo and Juliette which might give you an idea of the tragedy that's going to unfold."
"He is the greatest musician that ever lived and she is his match. So when she dies unexpectedly, he can't live without her so he journeys to the Underworld to bring her back."
The two main actors Credit: ITV News For this performance the Underworld is under one of the region's best known landmarks.
For years it was believed this giant structure was made of solid stone, until in 2002 engineers uncovered a series of huge vaulted chambers.
Brunel's detailed plans for his bridge have never been found but he almost certainly never imagined it would become a stage.
The Clifton Suspension Bridge Credit: ITV News Justin Palmer, the show's producer, is excited for the performances, and is intrigued to see what the audience's reactions will be.
He said: "I'm looking forward to seeing the audience's faces because if you've never been in here before- I'm kind of acclimatised to it but I still go 'wow, this is on the side of the gorge' but for the people who come here for the first time it's pretty exhilarating I think and you do feel like you've entered into a different kind of time zone."
And this extraordinary performance is already proving so popular they've had to put on extra dates. Orpheus and Eurydice be descending into the Bristol underworld until the middle of March.
